awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a Dual-Source Single-Crystal X-ray Diffractomter
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is supported by the Major Research Instrumentation and the Chemical Instrumentation Programs. Professor Andrew Sykes from the University of South Dakota (USD) and colleagues Haoran Sun and Zhenqiang Wang are acquiring a dual-source single-crystal diffractometer. In general, an X-ray diffractometer allows accurate and precise measurements of the full three-dimensional structure of a molecule, including bond distances and angles, and provides accurate information about the spatial arrangement of a molecule relative to neighboring molecules. The studies described here impact many areas, including organic and inorganic chemistry, materials chemistry and biochemistry. This instrument is an integral part of teaching as well as research and research training of undergraduate and graduate students in chemistry and biochemistry at this and other collaborating institutions. Because this is the only diffraction facility in the state it serves as a regional resource. The diffractometer also enables training of undergraduates at regional colleges and tribal schools with whom the home institution has long-established relationships through Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) programs. The instrument is also used extensively in the education and training of underrepresented students such as Native American students from Nebraska Indian Community College (NICC, in South Sioux City, Macy and Santee, NE) who participate in summer research at USD.

The award is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels. It is especially useful for studying  the absolute structure of steroids and for analyzing inorganic near-infrared active dyes with potential biomedical applications. The diffractometer is also employed to determine the structure of amphiphilic (detergent-like) molecules used in carbon-fluorine catalysis. The instrument is utilized in studies of anion sensors, fluorescent pressure sensors and anthraquinone-imine cation fluorescent sensors. It is also employed to characterize perfluoroalkylated transition metal complexes and metal-organic supercontainers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The University of South Dakota (USD) Department of Chemistry installed a Bruker AXS D8 Venture dual-source Single-Crystal X-ray Diffractometer (SC-SRD) in December of 2019. SC-XRD allows a three-dimensional view of molecules when able to form small crystals, including how these molecules interact with each other through non-covalent interactions. This technique allows for elemental analysis (the identity of each atom in the molecule) and the ability to understand chemical structure and maximize featured properties of molecules or materials in the solid-state, such as electrical conductivity and luminescence. The addition of this new instrument, which replaced our old diffractometer that was reaching the end of its useful lifetime has expanded the capabilities of collecting good diffraction data (including greater reliability, the use of multiple X-ray sources (Cu and Mo), and analyzing smaller crystals).  Over the past three years, the number of SC-XRD data collections using this new instrument has been documented as 625 total. Predominant use has been made by the Sykes, Sun, Hoefelmeyer and Wang research groups at USD. Sykes has characterized new luminescence sensors, Sun determined lamellar packing of perfluoroalkylated n-type semiconductors; Wang crystallized a new type of Metal-Organic Supercontainer (MOSCs), and Hoefelmeyer determined the structures of several Frustrated Lewis Pairs (FLPs).  Graduate training was conducted in the Solid State Chemistry and Crystallography course taught by the PI and on an individual basis for those graduate students whose research involved SC-XRD.  This instrument also impacted undergraduate students participating in our annual NSF-REU programs that involved synthesis and characterization of organic, inorganic, organometallic and materials projects. In addition, Dr. Michael Ruf from Bruker AXS came and gave a two-day advanced training workshop in April 2021.  The addition of this state-of-the-art instrument has allowed the Chemistry Department at USD to expand our capabilities and continue high quality chemical research involving the structural characterization of new molecules and materials.  We thank the NSF Division of Chemistry (CHE) and all associated Program Officers for their continuing support of the NSF-MRI program.

 


Last Modified: 01/05/2023
Modified by: Andrew G Sykes

Image
  • A new Bruker D8 Venture single-crystal X-ray diffractometer was installed in December 2019.
    University of South Dakota
    Copyrighted
    Andrew G Sykes
    USD Chemistry D8 Venture X-ray Diffraction

The addition of this new instrument, which replaced our old diffractometer that was reaching the end of its useful lifetime has expanded the capabilities of collecting good diffraction data (including greater reliability, the use of multiple X-ray sources (Cu and Mo), and analyzing smaller crystals). The addition of this state-of-the-art instrument has allowed the Chemistry Department at USD to expand our capabilities and continue high quality chemical research involving the structural characterization of new molecules and materials.  We thank the NSF Division of Chemistry (CHE) and all associated Program Officers for their continuing support of the NSF-MRI program.
